awd_titl_txt: Isomer selective interrogation of combustion and atmospheric intermediates
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism-A (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Bálint Sztáray of the University of the Pacific is using a combination of mass spectrometry and photoelectron spectroscopy to study the chemical reactions of unstable and elusive molecules that are relevant to atmospheric chemistry. Mass spectrometry is a technique that separates molecules or atoms according to their mass and electrical charge.  Photoelectron spectroscopy is a technique that uses light (typically from a laser) to eject electrons from atoms or molecules. The energy of the ejected electrons gives information about how strongly the electron was bound to the molecule. Professor Sztáray combines these two techniques to form photoelectron-photo-ion coincidence spectroscopy or "PEPICO", which provides a much more detailed molecular fingerprint, and enables the analysis of gaseous mixtures of many components. With a prototype instrument in Switzerland and with a new Sandia National Lab apparatus at the Advanced Light Source in Berkeley, reactions of unstable intermediate species, relevant in combustion, atmospheric, or interstellar environments are studied. The students involved in this project are receiving training in a cutting-edge experimental, highly collaborative environment.  As the research in the Sztáray laboratory involves custom-built instruments, graduate student researchers learn unique design and fabrication skills which are highly valued in the high-tech sector.  Graduate and undergraduate researchers also have opportunities to work with collaborators at US National Laboratories (Sandia and Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratories) as well as international facilities (Swiss Light Source).

In PEPICO coincidence detection, each photoelectron is "labeled" with the mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) of the photoion it corresponds to, essentially combining the advantages of mass spectrometry and photoelectron spectroscopy. Using a side-sampled, pulsed-laser photolysis flow-tube reactor, the project focuses on the spectroscopy and thermochemistry of elusive intermediates, such as alkylperoxy and hydroperoxyalkyl radicals, ketohydroperoxides and Criegee intermediates. Utilizing the isomer selectivity of PEPICO detection, a systematic study is conducted on the reactions of small carbon-containing radicals with small hydrocarbons. Recombination reactions of propargyl, allyl, and benzyl radicals play a crucial role in molecular weight growth processes that ultimately lead to soot formation. Here, PEPICO detection offers a step forward in understanding these reactive pathways and providing isomer selective branching ratios and reaction rates. Ultimately, by identifying key intermediates, their reaction mechanisms, and rates, more complete combustion models can be constructed, leading to better predictions of combustion products, including gaseous and aerosol pollutants.  These predictions can then aid  in the development of low-emission engine technologies.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
We are reporting on NSF grant CHE-1665464, Isomer selective interrogation of combustion and atmospheric intermediates, for $450,707 from August 1, 2017 to July 31, 2022, including a one-year no-cost extension and a one-year extension with COVID-19 relief supplemental funding. Using photoelectron photoion coincidence (PEPICO) spectroscopy, also coupled to a side-sampled pulsed-laser photolysis flow-tube reactor, this NSF-funded research focuses on the spectroscopy and thermochemistry of elusive intermediates, as well as the dissociation mechanisms of internal energy-selected ions. Results of our research funded by this NSF grant have been disseminated in 19 published papers and another manuscript is close to submission. Our results were also disseminated through oral and poster presentations.

Intellectual Merit

We have made substantial progress both with the photolysis PEPICO studies, where our technique was used as a highly selective detection method for transient species, as well as with the more “traditional” PEPICO experiments, in which we explored, modeled, and quantitatively explain ionic dissociation processes. Over the course of this funding cycle, we have collaborated and published with 14 other research groups, at both universities and (government) research institutes. In addition, our newly-built CRF-PEPICO prototype experiment at the SLS was used by 10–15 other research groups, leading to a further 50+ publications with this technique. These studies also served as springboard to the new CRF-PEPICO experiment, on which we collaborate with Sandia National Lab and which was recently commissioned at the Advanced Light Source synchrotron. Like its predecessor at the ALS, the Sandia multiplexed photoionization mass spectrometer, we anticipate that many research groups will be using this new tool with higher selectivity for their studies in atmospheric, combustion, or basic physical chemistry. Furthermore, PEPICO has been more than just a sophisticated detection method for studying short-lived intermediates in gas-phase reactions; we also kept utilizing it for more basic research in physical chemistry: exploring ionic isomerization/dissociation processes. We have unveiled complex dissociation mechanisms that were well-described by traditional transition states theory ­– but we also peeked beyond the TS, identifying bifurcations, non-statistical, excited state dynamics, and roaming dissociation pathways. These studies expanded our understanding of how unimolecular reactions proceed and the experimental part of this proposal is building directly on these prior results.

Broader Impact

University of the Pacific is situated in California’s Central Valley, which is historically underrepresented in higher education and research. Our students are often the first ones in the family to go to college. This is also true for our graduate students and the latest graduate student who defended in our research group comes from a local Filipino family. Two of our last three Ph.D.’s came from abroad and decided to stay in the U.S., filling important positions in the industry, while the other one became the first Ph.D. in his nearby hometown, also very successfully employed. Our graduate program is a joint venture with the School of Pharmacy and many of our graduate students come with a pharmaceutical background, using their multi-disciplinary skills in basic science. Because of our successful collaboration with the Swiss Light Source, Synchrotron Soleil, Sandia and Berkeley National Labs, our students had the opportunity to work in these inspiring research environments.

Our weekly research group meetings required our students to work on their oral communication, as well as critical thinking skills. To improve their written communication, undergraduate students finish each semester with short theses, while graduate students write research articles and create poster presentations for conferences. Our graduate program requires a yearly seminar talk given for the whole program and our students’ presentations were always well received and even awarded. Our experiments all involve custom-built instruments and the graduate students and postdocs learned unique design, fabrication, and maintenance skills. These skills positioned them well on the job market and they have been very successful in finding employment with instrumental analytical companies within weeks (or days) of graduation. Our last postdocs have both taken up teaching positions at universities and have been very successful at that.


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Balint Sztaray
